data.text: Should I Buy a Helios EV Hydrodown 300 Sleeping Bag?

A late spring summer sleeping bag, I'm thinking of this one Helios EV Hydrodown 300 Sleeping Bag, it's maybe a little on the warm side for summer, but better than being cold. Gooutdoors has a sub ¬£100 price at the moment but before I buy should I be looking at anything else.

I would read the reviews on that before you decide. Not a lot of good things said sadly. I was about to buy one last summer and decided better of it. Spent a bit more and got a Mountain Equipment Helium 400 that‚Äôs been superb.
data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: I had a quick look at reviews for the thing, didn't find anything particularly bad, I shall look again. Used to have a Helium, used it for years until I realised (after a good few years) that I could see through it. I'll have a look at them again.
data.author: Graham Lovatt

data.text: oh weird, I found a lot that said ‚Äúnot that warm‚Äù ‚Äúwouldn‚Äôt trust it down below 5deg‚Äù etc when I was looking. Really put me off.
data.author: Morgan Jones

data.text: unlikely I'd be using it below 5c so that bits OK. Was a quick look at reviews so maybe I should take a longer look
data.author: Graham Lovatt

data.text: personally I‚Äôd always like to have a 0deg bag in the uk, particularly if there‚Äôs a chance you‚Äôll camp high in spring or autumn and the temps drop. Better to be too warm overnight than too cold. Everyone is different though.

data.author: Larry Gowar

data.text: 'up north' sometimes seems that summer only lasts a few days and chances are we've blinked and missed it
data.author: Graham Lovatt

data.text: Summer set up for me is just a Snugpak Jungle Blanket XL and if needed a sleeping bag liner. Spring time is tricky though because it can be 16c in the day and 2c at night.
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: Barrett do you sleep warm ? do you not have to wear something, bit hard to believe that this jungle blanket would be as good as a sleeping bag. it does look interesting and at the price worth a try maybe
data.author: Graham Lovatt

data.text: I'm a fairly warm sleeper but honestly the blanket is still warm considering the thickness of it. I've slept on just a foam roll mat with the Jungle Blanket in a Snugpak Stratosphere without any chill in the summer. The blanket uses a good quality insulation so it's warmer than it looks. I simply wrap it around myself in the summer, winter months I wrap it around my sleeping bag to hold the temperature better. XL is massive but packs small, I'm 6'3 and around 15st and it's still plenty big enough to wrap around myself. My only complaint is it's quite a slippery material that can move around. The sleeping bag liner helps though and is good if it's slightly colder... Jungle Blanket XL is easily one of my favourite purchases and gets s good amount of use.
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: as you can see by the dimensions it's huge. Worth every penny üëç
data.author: Barrett Allen

data.text: Hmm, I have been considering the Softie 3 Merlin, pack size is similar but the jungle blanket is lighter cheaper. Might get both now‚Ä¶

data.text: Going out this Bank holiday will be using my Robens Serac 300. Last time I went out in April with it I froze so I am a little concerned. Will feedback to the group after the weekend or during if I have signal.
